physDesc.p: This letter is one page long. On the first page, the word “Poetry” is written in the top left corner and "(Monroe)" is written in pencil at the top center.

div.p: Of course, I quite understand that once a year is as much as anybody can appear on your front page, and I realize that the last time you put me there was in August, when you printed “1777” as your opening poem. I rather suppose that you would count this for the following year, but I am perfectly willing to have you put it at the end, and we will call my next contribution, whenever that may be, the opening one.

Six pages will be ample, and I am quite willing to leave to you the selection of the poems — although I think perhaps the short ones that the more striking, with the exception of the adaptation from Yakura Sanjin, which I personally think very lovely (and I can say that, as I am not responsible for it). However, as I say, you shall do exactly as you please about this group.
The lady who sent you two hundred dollars certainly deserves a vote of thanks from all of us.

I will appear at The Little Theatre at 4.30, on Sunday, February 25th. I am planning merely to read my poems, with just a few words of explanation where that seems necessary, but as few as possible. In other words, I consider this a reading, not a lecture, which is what I think you want.
I am looking forward to being in Chicago once more and seeing you.
